# quickwit Installation Guide

quickwit is a free and open-source search engine for logs. Quickwit provides cloud-native search engine for log management

## Table of Contents
1. [Prerequisites](#prerequisites)
2. [Supported Operating Systems](#supported-operating-systems)
3. [Installation](#installation)
4. [Configuration](#configuration)
5. [Service Management](#service-management)
6. [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
7. [Security Considerations](#security-considerations)
8. [Performance Tuning](#performance-tuning)
9. [Backup and Restore](#backup-and-restore)
10. [System Requirements](#system-requirements)
11. [Support](#support)
12. [Contributing](#contributing)
13. [License](#license)
14. [Acknowledgments](#acknowledgments)
15. [Version History](#version-history)
16. [Appendices](#appendices)

## 1. Prerequisites

- **Hardware Requirements**:
  - CPU: 2+ cores
  - RAM: 2GB minimum
  - Storage: 50GB for indices
  - Network: HTTP/gRPC
- **Operating System**: 
  - Linux: Any modern distribution (RHEL, Debian, Ubuntu, CentOS, Fedora, Arch, Alpine, openSUSE)
  - macOS: 10.14+ (Mojave or newer)
  - Windows: Windows Server 2016+ or Windows 10
  - FreeBSD: 11.0+
- **Network Requirements**:
  - Port 7280 (default quickwit port)
  - gRPC on 7281
- **Dependencies**:
  - See official documentation for specific requirements
- **System Access**: root or sudo privileges required


## 2. Supported Operating Systems

This guide supports installation on:
- RHEL 8/9 and derivatives (CentOS Stream, Rocky Linux, AlmaLinux)
- Debian 11/12
- Ubuntu 20.04/22.04/24.04 LTS
- Arch Linux (rolling release)
- Alpine Linux 3.18+
- openSUSE Leap 15.5+ / Tumbleweed
- SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES) 15+
- macOS 12+ (Monterey and later) 
- FreeBSD 13+
- Windows 10/11/Server 2019+ (where applicable)

## 3. Installation

### RHEL/CentOS/Rocky Linux/AlmaLinux

```bash
# Install EPEL repository if needed
sudo dnf install -y epel-release

# Install quickwit
sudo dnf install -y quickwit

# Enable and start service
sudo systemctl enable --now quickwit

# Configure firewall
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=7280/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### Debian/Ubuntu

```bash
# Update package index
sudo apt update

# Install quickwit
sudo apt install -y quickwit

# Enable and start service
sudo systemctl enable --now quickwit

# Configure firewall
sudo ufw allow 7280

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### Arch Linux

```bash
# Install quickwit
sudo pacman -S quickwit

# Enable and start service
sudo systemctl enable --now quickwit

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### Alpine Linux

```bash
# Install quickwit
apk add --no-cache quickwit

# Enable and start service
rc-update add quickwit default
rc-service quickwit start

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### openSUSE/SLES

```bash
# Install quickwit
sudo zypper install -y quickwit

# Enable and start service
sudo systemctl enable --now quickwit

# Configure firewall
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=7280/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### macOS

```bash
# Using Homebrew
brew install quickwit

# Start service
brew services start quickwit

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### FreeBSD

```bash
# Using pkg
pkg install quickwit

# Enable in rc.conf
echo 'quickwit_enable="YES"' >> /etc/rc.conf

# Start service
service quickwit start

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

### Windows

```bash
# Using Chocolatey
choco install quickwit

# Or using Scoop
scoop install quickwit

# Verify installation
quickwit --version
```

## Initial Configuration

### Basic Configuration

```bash
# Create configuration directory
sudo mkdir -p /etc/quickwit

# Set up basic configuration
# See official documentation for detailed configuration options

# Test configuration
quickwit --version
```

## 5. Service Management

### systemd (RHEL, Debian, Ubuntu, Arch, openSUSE)

```bash
# Enable service
sudo systemctl enable quickwit

# Start service
sudo systemctl start quickwit

# Stop service
sudo systemctl stop quickwit

# Restart service
sudo systemctl restart quickwit

# Check status
sudo systemctl status quickwit

# View logs
sudo journalctl -u quickwit -f
```

### OpenRC (Alpine Linux)

```bash
# Enable service
rc-update add quickwit default

# Start service
rc-service quickwit start

# Stop service
rc-service quickwit stop

# Restart service
rc-service quickwit restart

# Check status
rc-service quickwit status
```

### rc.d (FreeBSD)

```bash
# Enable in /etc/rc.conf
echo 'quickwit_enable="YES"' >> /etc/rc.conf

# Start service
service quickwit start

# Stop service
service quickwit stop

# Restart service
service quickwit restart

# Check status
service quickwit status
```

### launchd (macOS)

```bash
# Using Homebrew services
brew services start quickwit
brew services stop quickwit
brew services restart quickwit

# Check status
brew services list | grep quickwit
```

### Windows Service Manager

```powershell
# Start service
net start quickwit

# Stop service
net stop quickwit

# Using PowerShell
Start-Service quickwit
Stop-Service quickwit
Restart-Service quickwit

# Check status
Get-Service quickwit
```

## Advanced Configuration

See the official documentation for advanced configuration options.

## Reverse Proxy Setup

### nginx Configuration

```nginx
upstream quickwit_backend {
    server 127.0.0.1:7280;
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name quickwit.example.com;
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    server_name quickwit.example.com;

    ssl_certificate /etc/ssl/certs/quickwit.example.com.crt;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/ssl/private/quickwit.example.com.key;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://quickwit_backend;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
    }
}
```

### Apache Configuration

```apache
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName quickwit.example.com
    Redirect permanent / https://quickwit.example.com/
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:443>
    ServerName quickwit.example.com
    
    SSLEngine on
    SSLCertificateFile /etc/ssl/certs/quickwit.example.com.crt
    SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/ssl/private/quickwit.example.com.key
    
    ProxyRequests Off
    ProxyPreserveHost On
    
    ProxyPass / http://127.0.0.1:7280/
    ProxyPassReverse / http://127.0.0.1:7280/
</VirtualHost>
```

### HAProxy Configuration

```haproxy
frontend quickwit_frontend
    bind *:80
    bind *:443 ssl crt /etc/ssl/certs/quickwit.pem
    redirect scheme https if !{ ssl_fc }
    default_backend quickwit_backend

backend quickwit_backend
    balance roundrobin
    server quickwit1 127.0.0.1:7280 check
```

## Security Configuration

### Basic Security Setup

```bash
# Set appropriate permissions
sudo chown -R quickwit:quickwit /etc/quickwit
sudo chmod 750 /etc/quickwit

# Configure firewall
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=7280/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

# Enable SELinux policies (if applicable)
sudo setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect on
```

## Database Setup

See official documentation for database configuration requirements.

## Performance Optimization

### System Tuning

```bash
# Basic system tuning
echo 'net.core.somaxconn = 65535' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf
echo 'net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog = 65535' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf
sudo sysctl -p
```

## Monitoring

### Basic Monitoring

```bash
# Check service status
sudo systemctl status quickwit

# View logs
sudo journalctl -u quickwit -f

# Monitor resource usage
top -p $(pgrep quickwit)
```

## 9. Backup and Restore

### Backup Script

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# Basic backup script
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/quickwit"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p "$BACKUP_DIR"
tar -czf "$BACKUP_DIR/quickwit-backup-$DATE.tar.gz" /etc/quickwit /var/lib/quickwit

echo "Backup completed: $BACKUP_DIR/quickwit-backup-$DATE.tar.gz"
```

### Restore Procedure

```bash
# Stop service
sudo systemctl stop quickwit

# Restore from backup
tar -xzf /backup/quickwit/quickwit-backup-*.tar.gz -C /

# Start service
sudo systemctl start quickwit
```

## 6. Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

1. **Service won't start**:
```bash
# Check logs
sudo journalctl -u quickwit -n 100
sudo tail -f /var/log/quickwit/quickwit.log

# Check configuration
quickwit --version

# Check permissions
ls -la /etc/quickwit
```

2. **Connection issues**:
```bash
# Check if service is listening
sudo ss -tlnp | grep 7280

# Test connectivity
telnet localhost 7280

# Check firewall
sudo firewall-cmd --list-all
```

3. **Performance issues**:
```bash
# Check resource usage
top -p $(pgrep quickwit)

# Check disk I/O
iotop -p $(pgrep quickwit)

# Check connections
ss -an | grep 7280
```

## Integration Examples

### Docker Compose Example

```yaml
version: '3.8'
services:
  quickwit:
    image: quickwit:latest
    ports:
      - "7280:7280"
    volumes:
      - ./config:/etc/quickwit
      - ./data:/var/lib/quickwit
    restart: unless-stopped
```

## Maintenance

### Update Procedures

```bash
# RHEL/CentOS/Rocky/AlmaLinux
sudo dnf update quickwit

# Debian/Ubuntu
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade quickwit

# Arch Linux
sudo pacman -Syu quickwit

# Alpine Linux
apk update && apk upgrade quickwit

# openSUSE
sudo zypper update quickwit

# FreeBSD
pkg update && pkg upgrade quickwit

# Always backup before updates
tar -czf /backup/quickwit-pre-update-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz /etc/quickwit

# Restart after updates
sudo systemctl restart quickwit
```

### Regular Maintenance

```bash
# Log rotation
sudo logrotate -f /etc/logrotate.d/quickwit

# Clean old logs
find /var/log/quickwit -name "*.log" -mtime +30 -delete

# Check disk usage
du -sh /var/lib/quickwit
```

## Additional Resources

- Official Documentation: https://docs.quickwit.org/
- GitHub Repository: https://github.com/quickwit/quickwit
- Community Forum: https://forum.quickwit.org/
- Best Practices Guide: https://docs.quickwit.org/best-practices

# Elasticsearch Installation Guide

Elasticsearch is a free and open-source distributed, RESTful search and analytics engine. Originally developed by Shay Banon and now maintained by Elastic N.V., Elasticsearch is built on Apache Lucene and designed for horizontal scalability, reliability, and real-time search. It serves as a FOSS alternative to commercial search solutions like Amazon CloudSearch, Azure Cognitive Search, or Splunk Enterprise, offering enterprise-grade features including full-text search, aggregations, and analytics without licensing costs, with features like distributed architecture, RESTful API, and multi-tenancy.

## Table of Contents
1. [Prerequisites](#prerequisites)
2. [Supported Operating Systems](#supported-operating-systems)
3. [Installation](#installation)
4. [Configuration](#configuration)
5. [Service Management](#service-management)
6. [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
7. [Security Considerations](#security-considerations)
8. [Performance Tuning](#performance-tuning)
9. [Backup and Restore](#backup-and-restore)
10. [System Requirements](#system-requirements)
11. [Support](#support)
12. [Contributing](#contributing)
13. [License](#license)
14. [Acknowledgments](#acknowledgments)
15. [Version History](#version-history)
16. [Appendices](#appendices)

## 1. Prerequisites

- **Hardware Requirements**:
  - CPU: 2 cores minimum (4+ cores recommended for production)
  - RAM: 4GB minimum (16GB+ recommended for production)
  - Storage: 20GB minimum (SSD strongly recommended for performance)
  - Network: Stable connectivity for cluster communication
- **Operating System**: 
  - Linux: Any modern distribution with kernel 3.2+
  - macOS: 10.13+ (High Sierra or newer)
  - Windows: Windows Server 2016+ or Windows 10
  - FreeBSD: 11.0+
- **Network Requirements**:
  - Port 9200 (HTTP/REST API)
  - Port 9300 (Node communication)
  - Additional ports for cluster discovery
- **Dependencies**:
  - Java 11 or Java 17 (OpenJDK recommended)
  - systemd or compatible init system (Linux)
  - Root or administrative access for installation
- **System Access**: root or sudo privileges required


## 2. Supported Operating Systems

This guide supports installation on:
- RHEL 8/9 and derivatives (CentOS Stream, Rocky Linux, AlmaLinux)
- Debian 11/12
- Ubuntu 20.04/22.04/24.04 LTS
- Arch Linux (rolling release)
- Alpine Linux 3.18+
- openSUSE Leap 15.5+ / Tumbleweed
- SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES) 15+
- macOS 12+ (Monterey and later) 
- FreeBSD 13+
- Windows 10/11/Server 2019+ (where applicable)

## 3. Installation

### RHEL/CentOS/Rocky Linux/AlmaLinux

```bash
# Install Java (OpenJDK)
sudo yum install -y java-11-openjdk java-11-openjdk-devel

# Import Elasticsearch GPG key
sudo rpm --import https://artifacts.elastic.co/GPG-KEY-elasticsearch

# Create Elasticsearch repository
sudo tee /etc/yum.repos.d/elasticsearch.repo <<EOF
[elasticsearch]
name=Elasticsearch repository for 8.x packages
baseurl=https://artifacts.elastic.co/packages/8.x/yum
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=https://artifacts.elastic.co/GPG-KEY-elasticsearch
enabled=0
autorefresh=1
type=rpm-md
EOF

# Install Elasticsearch
sudo yum install -y --enablerepo=elasticsearch elasticsearch

# Enable and start service
sudo systemctl enable --now elasticsearch

# Configure firewall
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=9200/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=9300/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

# Verify installation
curl -X GET "localhost:9200/"
```

### Debian/Ubuntu


```nginx

upstream elasticsearch_backend {
    server 127.0.0.1:9200 max_fails=3 fail_timeout=30s;
    server 127.0.0.1:9201 max_fails=3 fail_timeout=30s backup;
}

    server_name elasticsearch.example.com;
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

    server_name elasticsearch.example.com;

    ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/elasticsearch.example.com/privkey.pem;

    add_header Strict-Transport-Security "max-age=63072000" always;

        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Host $http_host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
        proxy_connect_timeout 60s;
        proxy_send_timeout 60s;
        proxy_read_timeout 60s;
    }
```

### Backup Procedures

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# elasticsearch-backup.sh

SNAPSHOT_NAME="snapshot-$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)"

# Create snapshot
curl -X PUT "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/$SNAPSHOT_NAME?wait_for_completion=true" -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d'
{
  "indices": "*",
  "ignore_unavailable": true,
  "include_global_state": true,
  "metadata": {
    "taken_by": "elasticsearch-backup-script",
    "taken_because": "scheduled backup"
  }
}'

# Verify snapshot
SNAPSHOT_STATUS=$(curl -s "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/$SNAPSHOT_NAME" | jq -r '.snapshots[0].state')

if [ "$SNAPSHOT_STATUS" = "SUCCESS" ]; then
    echo "Backup completed successfully: $SNAPSHOT_NAME"
else
    echo "Backup failed: $SNAPSHOT_NAME"
    exit 1
fi

# Clean up old snapshots (keep last 7 days)
curl -s "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/_all" | jq -r '.snapshots[] | select(.end_time_in_millis < '$(date -d '7 days ago' +%s000)') | .snapshot' | while read snapshot; do
    curl -X DELETE "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/$snapshot"
    echo "Deleted old snapshot: $snapshot"
done

echo "Elasticsearch backup completed: $SNAPSHOT_NAME"
```

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# elasticsearch-restore.sh

SNAPSHOT_NAME="$1"
if [ -z "$SNAPSHOT_NAME" ]; then
    echo "Usage: $0 <snapshot-name>"
    echo "Available snapshots:"
```

Elasticsearch is a free and open-source distributed, RESTful search and analytics engine. Originally developed by Shay Banon and now maintained by Elastic N.V., Elasticsearch is built on Apache Lucene and designed for horizontal scalability, reliability, and real-time search. It serves as a FOSS alternative to commercial search solutions like Amazon CloudSearch, Azure Cognitive Search, or Splunk Enterprise, offering enterprise-grade features including full-text search, aggregations, and analytics without licensing costs, with features like distributed architecture, RESTful API, and multi-tenancy.

1. Prerequisites

  • RAM: 4GB minimum (16GB+ recommended for production)

  • Network: Stable connectivity for cluster communication

    #!/bin/bash
# elasticsearch-backup.sh

SNAPSHOT_NAME="snapshot-$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)"

# Create snapshot

  }
}'

# Verify snapshot
SNAPSHOT_STATUS=$(curl -s "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/$SNAPSHOT_NAME" | jq -r '.snapshots[0].state')

if [ "$SNAPSHOT_STATUS" = "SUCCESS" ]; then
    echo "Backup completed successfully: $SNAPSHOT_NAME"
else
    echo "Backup failed: $SNAPSHOT_NAME"
    exit 1
fi

# Clean up old snapshots (keep last 7 days)
curl -s "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/_all" | jq -r '.snapshots[] | select(.end_time_in_millis < '$(date -d '7 days ago' +%s000)') | .snapshot' | while read snapshot; do
    curl -X DELETE "localhost:9200/_snapshot/backup_repo/$snapshot"

done

echo "Elasticsearch backup completed: $SNAPSHOT_NAME"

## 1. Prerequisites

- **Hardware Requirements**:
  - CPU: 1 core minimum
  - RAM: 512MB minimum
  - Storage: 10GB for indices
  - Network: HTTP API
- **Operating System**: 
  - Linux: Any modern distribution (RHEL, Debian, Ubuntu, CentOS, Fedora, Arch, Alpine, openSUSE)
  - macOS: 10.14+ (Mojave or newer)
  - Windows: Windows Server 2016+ or Windows 10
  - FreeBSD: 11.0+
- **Network Requirements**:
  - Port 8000 (default lnx port)
  - None
- **Dependencies**:
  - See official documentation for specific requirements
- **System Access**: root or sudo privileges required


## 2. Supported Operating Systems

This guide supports installation on:
- RHEL 8/9 and derivatives (CentOS Stream, Rocky Linux, AlmaLinux)
- Debian 11/12
- Ubuntu 20.04/22.04/24.04 LTS
- Arch Linux (rolling release)
- Alpine Linux 3.18+

- Windows 10/11/Server 2019+ (where applicable)

## Reverse Proxy Setup

### nginx Configuration

```nginx
upstream lnx_backend {
    server 127.0.0.1:8000;
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name lnx.example.com;
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    server_name lnx.example.com;

    ssl_certificate /etc/ssl/certs/lnx.example.com.crt;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/ssl/private/lnx.example.com.key;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://lnx_backend;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
    }
}
```

### Apache Configuration

```apache
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName lnx.example.com
    Redirect permanent / https://lnx.example.com/
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:443>
    ServerName lnx.example.com
    
    SSLEngine on
    SSLCertificateFile /etc/ssl/certs/lnx.example.com.crt
    SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/ssl/private/lnx.example.com.key
    
    ProxyRequests Off
    ProxyPreserveHost On
    
    ProxyPass / http://127.0.0.1:8000/
    ProxyPassReverse / http://127.0.0.1:8000/
</VirtualHost>
```

```haproxy
frontend lnx_frontend

    bind *:443 ssl crt /etc/ssl/certs/lnx.pem
    redirect scheme https if !{ ssl_fc }
    default_backend lnx_backend

    balance roundrobin
    server lnx1 127.0.0.1:8000 check
```
